    Introduction: Density ratio estimation for covariate shift

    Extract summary from ulsif object, including two-sample significance test for homogeneity of the numerator and denominator samples

    summary.ulsif.Rd

    Extract summary from ulsif object, including two-sample significance test for homogeneity of the numerator and denominator samples

    Usage

    # S3 method for ulsif
summary(
  object,
  test = FALSE,
  n_perm = 100,
  parallel = FALSE,
  cluster = NULL,
  ...
)

    Arguments

    object

    Object of class ulsif

    test

    logical indicating whether to statistically test for homogeneity of the numerator and denominator samples.

    n_perm

    Scalar indicating number of permutation samples

    parallel

    logical indicating to run the permutation test in parallel

    cluster

    NULL or a cluster object created by makeCluster. If NULL and parallel = TRUE, it uses the number of available cores minus 1.

    ...

    further arguments passed to or from other methods.

    Value

    Summary of the fitted density ratio model

    Examples

    set.seed(123)
# Fit model
dr <- ulsif(numerator_small, denominator_small)
# Inspect model object
dr
#> 
#> Call:
#> ulsif(df_numerator = numerator_small, df_denominator = denominator_small)
#> 
#> Kernel Information:
#>   Kernel type: Gaussian with L2 norm distances
#>   Number of kernels: 150
#>   sigma: num [1:10] 0.717 1.081 1.335 1.541 1.743 ...
#> 
#> Regularization parameter (lambda): num [1:20] 1000 483.3 233.6 112.9 54.6 ...
#> 
#> Optimal sigma (loocv): 1.540846
#> Optimal lambda (loocv): 2.976351
#> Optimal kernel weights (loocv): num [1:151] 0.0663 0.0289 0.0424 0.0442 0.0454 ...
#>  
# Obtain summary of model object
summary(dr)
#> 
#> Call:
#> ulsif(df_numerator = numerator_small, df_denominator = denominator_small)
#> 
#> Kernel Information:
#>   Kernel type: Gaussian with L2 norm distances
#>   Number of kernels: 150
#> 
#> Optimal sigma: 1.540846
#> Optimal lambda: 2.976351
#> Optimal kernel weights: num [1:151] 0.0663 0.0289 0.0424 0.0442 0.0454 ...
#>  
#> Pearson divergence between P(nu) and P(de): 0.3866
#> For a two-sample homogeneity test, use 'summary(x, test = TRUE)'.
#> 
# Plot model object
plot(dr)
#> Warning: Negative estimated density ratios for 2 observation(s) converted to 0.01 before applying logarithmic transformation
#> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

# Plot density ratio for each variable individually
plot_univariate(dr)
#> Warning: Negative estimated density ratios for 2 observation(s) converted to 0.01 before applying logarithmic transformation
#> [[1]]

#> 
#> [[2]]

#> 
#> [[3]]

#> 
# Plot density ratio for each pair of variables
plot_bivariate(dr)
#> Warning: Negative estimated density ratios for 2 observation(s) converted to 0.01 before applying logarithmic transformation
#> [[1]]

#> 
#> [[2]]

#> 
#> [[3]]

#> 
# Predict density ratio and inspect first 6 predictions
head(predict(dr))
#> , , 1
#> 
#>           [,1]
#> [1,] 0.9857749
#> [2,] 1.2896441
#> [3,] 1.5090336
#> [4,] 1.2829775
#> [5,] 1.0964401
#> [6,] 1.5274078
#> 
# Fit model with custom parameters
ulsif(numerator_small, denominator_small, sigma = 2, lambda = 2)
#> 
#> Call:
#> ulsif(df_numerator = numerator_small, df_denominator = denominator_small,     sigma = 2, lambda = 2)
#> 
#> Kernel Information:
#>   Kernel type: Gaussian with L2 norm distances
#>   Number of kernels: 150
#>   sigma: num 2
#> 
#> Regularization parameter (lambda): num 2
#> 
#> Optimal sigma (loocv): 2
#> Optimal lambda (loocv): 2
#> Optimal kernel weights (loocv): num [1:151] 0.0378 0.0348 0.0554 0.053 0.0619 ...
#>
